title: SB 1073
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 17052 of the Revenue and Taxation Code is amended to allow an earned income tax credit against the "net tax" for taxable years starting January 1, 2015. The credit amount is determined based on Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code, with adjustments specified in the annual Budget Act. The earned income tax credit adjustment factor for taxable years starting January 1, 2015, is 0 percent unless specified in the annual Budget Act. The credit is only available when resources are allocated in the Budget Act for oversight and auditing. The credit percentage and phaseout percentage vary based on the number of qualifying children. The earned income tax credit varies based on the number of qualifying children, with different credit and phaseout percentages. The earned income amount and phaseout amount also differ depending on the number of qualifying children. Modifications to certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code are made for eligible individuals. The earned income tax credit varies based on the number of qualifying children, with different credit and phaseout percentages. Modifications to certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code are made for eligible individuals, including adjustments to income thresholds and qualifying child criteria. Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code is modified for eligible individuals, including adjustments to income thresholds and qualifying child criteria. The earned income tax credit amount is recomputed annually, and any excess credit can be used to offset other tax liabilities or refunded to the taxpayer. The Franchise Tax Board may prescribe rules to carry out the purposes of this section, and amounts refunded will be treated similarly to federal earned income refunds for determining eligibility for benefits under the Welfare and Institutions Code. Amounts refunded under this section will be treated like federal earned income refunds for determining eligibility for benefits under the Welfare and Institutions Code. The Franchise Tax Board is exempt from certain requirements for implementing the credit for the 2015 taxable year. The Franchise Tax Board is required to include the scope, costs, and schedule changes for the California Earned Income Tax Credit in its Special Project Report. The purpose of the credit is to reduce poverty among working families and individuals in California, and the Board must annually report on the number of tax returns claiming the credit. The Franchise Tax Board must report on the number of tax returns claiming the California Earned Income Tax Credit, including details such as the average credit amount, distribution by dependents and income ranges, and estimates of families lifted out of deep poverty by the credit. The Franchise Tax Board will provide a report on the California Earned Income Tax Credit to various Senate and Assembly committees. The tax credit will apply to taxable years starting from January 1, 2016.
